The story takes place in the Twilight Lab, near the northern pole of Mercury. There is a rocket landing, labs and quarters for Sanderson’s crew sunk deep into the crust, and the tower that housed the Solar ’scope that Sanderson had built up there ten years before. Sanderson built the Lab up near the pole, where the zone only varies 50 to 60 degrees with the libration of Mercury, so the temperature only varies up to 50-60 degrees. The Solar �’scope could take that much change and they’d get good clear observation of the Sun for about seventy out of the eighty-eight days it takes the planet to wheel around. The Twilight Lab wasn’t particularly interested in the Brightside, but it was chosen because it was the closest chunk of rock to the Sun that could hold his observatory. The Major was counting on Sanderson knowing something about Mercury as well as the Sun when they camped at the Lab to make final preparations. 

Jack Stone, the third member of the party, who had arrived with supplies and equipment a few days earlier, almost bawled when Sanderson gave him such a gloomy picture of what Brightside was like. Stone was a youngster—hardly twenty-five, but he begged to join the Major and had been with the Major at Vulcan. He thought Mikuta was God, followed him around like a puppy.

The story begins with Retief and Hank Arapoulous sitting in the office of the secretary of the Bogan Academy of Interplanetary Flight. They are talking about how they are going to send a group of Bogan students to Lovenbroy on a two-ship trip to harvest the grape harvest. They discuss how they need to find a way to get the students to the port in time. Hank tells Retief that he has two thousand men for the harvest, but Retief asks him for a thousand. Hank says he has 100 men, and Retief tells him that a thousand would be better. Hank agrees, and they go to the warehouse to see if there is a problem with the baggage. When they arrive at the warehouse, they find that there is no luggage in the baggage compartment. They ask the dispatch clerk to check on the shipment, but the clerk tells them that the shipment has been sent to d’Land, but it is not there. They go back to the Port Authority, where they find out that the baggage is actually being transported to the other side of the border. They return to the Departures enclosure at the port, where Retief meets Karsh, the captain of the ship. Karsh is upset that the students are not loaded on the ship, and he asks Retief to cover for him. Retief explains that he is covering for a friend who slipped up, and Karsh says he will send a written change order in the morning that will cover him officially. When Retief goes to see the baggage, he finds out that it is loaded with 2mm needlers, Mark XII hand blasters, power pistols, and other weapons. He asks Karsh to check the baggage again, but Karsh refuses to do so. When he goes back to check it again, Retief finds that the bags are not there, but are instead being transported on a different ship. When Karsh tries to find out why, he is stopped by the port authorities, who tell him that they have no idea why the baggage isn’t there. The next day, when Retief returns to the airport, he learns that the luggage is actually on the other ship, the one that was supposed to go to d'Land, and that it’s been ticketed clear through the port. He calls Karsh again and asks him to check his luggage again, and when Karsh returns, he says that it has been changed to the ship that is actually going to Lovernbroy. 

Retief tells Karsh that he wants to go see the students personally, and asks if they are all loaded and ready to go, but he is told that they are not. He then goes to the departure enclosure and sees that there are no students on the two ships.

Dimanche is a device that is attached to the body of a man named Cassal. He is able to communicate with Cassal via subvocalization, which is what Cassal uses to communicate back to the police. Dimanche can also scan nervous systems, collect and interpret physiological data, and report what a person says to him. He has a high level of adrenalin in his system, which makes him feel like he is being stalked by a man who is intent on assault. He can also detect that the man has murder in his mind, so he suggests that Cassal report the assault to the godful police. However, he is unable to give the police any evidence save for the fact that he can read minds.

Cassal is traveling to Tunney 21, a planet in the middle of the Milky Way Galaxy. He is on his way to see Rickrock C, the man who tried to kill him last night. He has been selected to travel to the planet because he is the best salesman that Neuronics, Inc., has to have, and he is a good sales engineer. Cassal does not want to go back to Earth because he does not believe that it is practical to send back for anything over such distances. He knows that he will not be able to save the company and not even them if he goes to see him.

Murra Foray is the first counselor at Travelers Aid. She is described to be a Huntner, a sub-race of men from the other side of the Galaxy. She has a bright, bright face and bright eyes, and her eyes are bright enough to make Cassal believe that she is much younger than she is. She also has bright eyes that make him think that she must be much older than she actually is. When he first meets her, she tells him that her name is Murra, and she is a first counselor. She tells him about her home planet, where she is from, and how she was able to locate him when he first arrives at the agency. They accept contributions, and they will give him a sum so that he will not have to compromise his standard living to get to Tunney 21.

The story takes place on the planet of Godolph. It is described as a city with a lot of traffic. There is also a large amount of traffic on the streets. Appointment in Tomorrow is a story about two explorers, Gwayne and Barker, who are on a mission to find a new planet to explore. They are led by Gwayne to the headquarters of Captain Hennessy, a former friend of Gwayne’s, who has been captured by the blobs. Gwayne is a captain of a ship that has been sent to explore the planet in search of a new world to explore, and Barker is the doctor on the ship. The story begins with Gwayne trying to convince Barker to let him go back to the ship, but the doctor refuses. She tells them about her memories of Bram, a young man who came to live in the bar when she was a young woman, and how many children he had. The story ends with the two of them leaving the bar together, and Gwayne leading the group of explorers out of the building.

Maizie is the brain-machine of Jorj Helmuth, who is the President’s Secretary of State. She is a machine that has been created by the Thinkers, a group of people who have been working on a project to create a new type of brain-machines. The machine is controlled by the President and the Secretary of Space, who are both pleased that the machine was created because it gives them power over the Administration. The machine is able to communicate with the President, the Secretary, and the other members of the Administration, and even the President himself. It is also important because it is the reason that the President decides to send the Secretary and the President to Mars in the first place, and it is also the reason for the creation of the machine.

The Thinkers are a group of people who are trying to control the future of the human race. They are described as having the power of a few lucky guesses, based on some science hocus-pocus and faith-healing. They believe that they have the power to create peace, honor, and a good conscience for the world. They also believe that the world needs peace and honor, which is what the world hasn’t got. Therefore, they are able to manipulate the minds of the people in the Inner Cabinet and the President of the U.S. in order to get them to give in to their wishes. The Thinkers’ power is also based on the fact that they know that they are going to have to produce an actual nuclear rocket soon, and for that they’ll need our help. 

They are also the reason that the President’s wife is given mental comfort, which gives her false comfort. The President also believes that the Soviets pulled out of Iraq and Iran because of the Mind Bomb threat, but the truth is that they pulled out because of a brain-machine that is just a cover for Jan Tregarron's guesswork.

Opperly meets Farquar, who is the leader of the Thinkers, at the beginning of the story. Farquar is one of the most important characters in the story, as he is the one who invites Opperly to join him on his mission to find a way to defeat the Thinkers. . They take them to the hospital, and Star shoots two of the men he shot down. He then wakes up in a cell, where he is told that he will be executed.

Star is a tall, black-haired girl with dark-eyed eyes and black hair that looks like silken spun darkness. Ed and Verana are close friends who have known each other for a long time. They have been working together for a while, and they have a good relationship. The story begins with Dimanche and Cassal, the first counselor of Travelers Aid, Dimanche’s right-hand man, trying to track down the woman, Murra Foray, who is a Huntner, a sub-race of men on the other side of the Galaxy.
